2025-05-03 20:23:22,272 - together_inference - INFO - [{'role': 'system', 'content': 'You are given one sentence related to the Central Bank of the Philippines\' monetary policy meeting. You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bsp}{five} Policy, Environment, Society, Market, and Trade.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Policy}: Decisions implemented by the government or its institutions to regulate, direct, or influence national affairs. Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: [2] at the same time, the committee also submitted its monetary policy recommendations to the monetary board.\n                "}]

"label": "irrelevant",
"justification": "The sentence only mentions the submission of monetary policy recommendations without providing any information about the stance or decision."

\\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: nonetheless, the increasing level of the country’s gross international reserves likewise provided broad stability to the peso.\n                "}]
2025-05-03 20:23:26,385 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The increasing level of gross international reserves providing stability to the peso suggests a positive development, which could lead to a more accommodative monetary policy."
}

in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: towards the close of the month, the index moved sideways.\n                "}]

"justification": "The sentence does not mention any monetary policy decisions or indicators, and only describes the movement of an index, making it irrelevant to the monetary policy stance."

Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: - indicators suggest and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in particular, the members of the monetary board indicated their willingness in the future to resort to monetary tightening measures should conditions in the foreign exchange market continue to point to a severe depreciation of the peso which could threaten the inflation target over the policy horizon.\n                "}]

"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence indicates a willingness to resort to monetary tightening measures in the future, which signals a contractionary monetary policy stance."

indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the special deposit account - relative to their 11 july levels, secondary market yields of government securities (gs) in end-july and on 14 august showed mixed trends.\n                "}]
2025-05-03 20:23:38,376 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence describes market trends without indicating a change in monetary policy or a clear direction, hence it is neutral."
}

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bsp}{five} Policy, Environment, Society, Market, and Trade.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Policy}: Decisions implemented by the government or its institutions to regulate, direct, or influence national affairs. Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: moreover, the number of cpi items with inflation rates below the threshold dropped in may relative to the previous month.\n                "}]

Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: improvements in business and consumer outlook for the fourth quarter of 2005 and for the first quarter of 2006. unemployed, which include all persons who are 15 years old and over as of their last birthday and are reported as: (1) without work and currently available for work and seeking work; or (2) without work and currently available for work but not seeking work for the following reasons: (a) tired/believed no work available; (b) awaiting results of previous job application; (c) temporary illness/disability; (d) bad weather; and (e) waiting for rehire/job recall.\n                "}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "Improvements in business and consumer outlook, along with a description of unemployment, suggest a positive economic outlook, which may lead to monetary easing."
}

\\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the latest growth estimates are lower due to weaker-than-expected observations from high-frequency indicators and global economic conditions.\n                "}]

Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bsp}{five} Policy, Environment, Society, Market, and Trade.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Policy}: Decisions implemented by the government or its institutions to regulate, direct, or influence national affairs. Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the cumulative growth rate for january-july was 6.3 percent, considerably lower than the previous year’s 17.6 percent.\n                "}]

"label": "irrelevant",
"justification": "The sentence only reports on growth rate data without mentioning any monetary policy decision or implication."
}

November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the mb also reiterated its readiness to employ macroprudential measures as necessary to pre-emptively address any potential misalignment in asset prices.\n                "}]

Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bsp}{five} Policy, Environment, Society, Market, and Trade.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Policy}: Decisions implemented by the government or its institutions to regulate, direct, or influence national affairs. Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: percent from 80.1 percent (revised) in the previous month.\n                "}]

against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: mean inflation forecast for 2017 stood at 2.9 percent.\n                "}]
2025-05-03 20:24:04,102 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence only reports a forecast without indicating any change in monetary policy or stance."
}

Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated increase in taxes of sweetened beverages serves as a possible upside risk to inflation.\n                "}]
2025-05-03 20:24:07,340 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The proposed increase in taxes on sweetened beverages is seen as a possible upside risk to inflation, which may lead to contractionary monetary policy."
}

2025-05-03 20:24:07,997 - together_inference - INFO - [{'role': 'system', 'content': 'You are given one sentence related to the Central Bank of the Philippines\' monetary policy meeting. You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bsp}{five} Policy, Environment, Society, Market, and Trade.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Policy}: Decisions implemented by the government or its institutions to regulate, direct, or influence national affairs. Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: - at the same time, the risks to the inflation outlook lean strongly toward the upside for 2022 and 2023 but are seen to remain broadly balanced for 2024.\n                "}]
2025-05-03 20:24:07,997 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence indicates that the risks to the inflation outlook lean strongly toward the upside, suggesting a potential need for contractionary monetary policy to control inflation."
}

\\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: meanwhile, netting out the interest payments in the expenditures, the primary surplus amounted to p202.7 billion, p56.4 billion higher than the level recorded in the period january-august 2013.\n                "}]
2025-05-03 20:24:11,882 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "irrelevant",
"justification": "The sentence discusses the primary surplus and interest payments, which are not directly related to the Central Bank's monetary policy stance."
}

demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: for 2011, the mean inflation forecast was also slightly lower at 4.6 percent from 4.7 percent.\n                "}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "A lower inflation forecast indicates room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation."
}

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bsp}{five} Policy, Environment, Society, Market, and Trade.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Policy}: Decisions implemented by the government or its institutions to regulate, direct, or influence national affairs. Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: higher inflation in january was traced mainly to higher prices of food and energy items.\n                "}]
