Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: additionally, higher oil prices were partly supported by expectations of interest rate cuts by the us federal reserve in 2024; us plans to increase its crude stockpiles; and favorable indicators of economic activity in china.\n                "}]
2025-05-03 20:24:20,104 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence mentions expectations of interest rate cuts by the US Federal Reserve, which signals a potential easing of monetary policy."
}

subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: however, given evidence of weakness in domestic demand conditions and benign inflationary setting, some members of the monetary board also noted that current monetary policy stance might risk being too tight.\n                "}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence suggests that the current monetary policy stance might be too tight, implying a need for easing, which is a dovish stance."
}

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bsp}{five} Policy, Environment, Society, Market, and Trade.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Policy}: Decisions implemented by the government or its institutions to regulate, direct, or influence national affairs. Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: - the fiscal deficit in january-june 2011 was p17.2 billion, 91.2 percent lower than the p196.7 billion deficit incurred during the same period last year.\n                "}]

"label": "irrelevant",
"justification": "The sentence discusses the fiscal deficit, which is not directly related to the Central Bank of the Philippines' monetary policy meeting."
}

\\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: - treasury bill (t-bill) auction rates eased across all tenors on 31 july 2006 relative to 26 june 2006 due to strong demand for t-bills amid ample liquidity and an improving fiscal position.\n                "}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "Eased treasury bill auction rates and strong demand for t-bills amid ample liquidity indicate a decrease in interest rates, signaling a dovish monetary policy stance."
}

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bsp}{five} Policy, Environment, Society, Market, and Trade.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Policy}: Decisions implemented by the government or its institutions to regulate, direct, or influence national affairs. Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} 2025-05-03 20:24:36,009 - together_inference - INFO - [{'role': 'system', 'content': 'You are given one sentence related to the Central Bank of the Philippines\' monetary policy meeting. You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bsp}{five} Policy, Environment, Society, Market, and Trade.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Policy}: Decisions implemented by the government or its institutions to regulate, direct, or influence national affairs. Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: nevertheless, the growth in agriculture is projected to accelerate in the quarter due to higher palay and corn production.\n                "}]

"label": "irrelevant",
"justification": "The sentence discusses agriculture growth and production, which is not related to monetary policy."

November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: slower growth in government Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bsp}{five} Policy, Environment, Society, Market, and Trade.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Policy}: Decisions implemented by the government or its institutions to regulate, direct, or influence national affairs. Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the ng recorded a p90.2-billion fiscal deficit for q1 2019, which is forty-one percent lower than that recorded in - global economic growth is seen to slow down in 2019 but is expected to pick up in 2020.\n                "}]

recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: - based on the assessment by the us climate prediction center and international research institute for climate and society (cpc/iri) as of 14 march 2024, el niño conditions continued to weaken and will likely transition to enso-neutral during april – june 2024 with chances of la niña developing by june – august 2024.\n                "}]

Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: this represented collections increased by 11.1 percent while expenditure was higher by 14.5 percent.\n                "}]

"label": "irrelevant",
"justification": "The sentence only discusses collections and expenditure without mentioning any monetary policy decisions or implications."
}

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bsp}{five} Policy, Environment, Society, Market, and Trade.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Policy}: Decisions implemented by the government or its institutions to regulate, direct, or influence national affairs. Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the highlights of the discussions during the 23 march 2017 meeting were approved by the monetary board during the mb considered the following developments in deciding on the monetary policy stance: - inflation in february 2017 increased to 3.3 percent from 2.7 percent in january 2017, which is the highest outturn since november 2014.\n                "}]

Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the 2000 and 1994 headline and core inflation series will continue to be published until june 2004, after which, only the 2000–based cpi headline and core inflation data will be reported.\n                "}]

"label": "irrelevant",
"justification": "The sentence discusses the publication of inflation series data and does not mention any monetary policy decisions or indicators."

levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: - the philippine business cycle (measured as the trend cycle of growth rate for industry and services) eased for the third consecutive quarter in q3 2018 but remained above the long-term growth trend.\n                "}]
2025-05-03 20:24:56,806 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence discusses the Philippine business cycle, which is a market indicator, but does not imply any change in monetary policy or stance."
}

Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bsp}{five} Policy, Environment, Society, Market, and Trade.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Policy}: Decisions implemented by the government or its institutions to regulate, direct, or influence national affairs. Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Maintaining existing interest rates indicates no change in monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The Monetary Board (MB) decided to: a) Increase the BSP’s key policy interest rate by 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to recession concerns is likely to drive inflation higher, creating a need for contractionary monetary policy to ensure the stability of the peso and the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``Moreover, unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals monetary easing to stimulate the economy. \n\n    \\item ``Compared to the previous policy meeting, baseline inflation forecast for 2013 has been revised downward due primarily to lower oil prices.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation forecasts indicate room for monetary easing without the risks of high inflation.\n\n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions during the 9 November 2017 monetary policy meeting were approved by the Monetary Board during its regular meeting held on 28 November 2017.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence mentions the approval of a past discussion with no mention of a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: policy uncertainty such as the state of regulatory and fiscal policies in the us, spillovers from tighter global financial conditions, and geopolitical risks as the primary downside risks to global growth over the medium term.\n                "}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence mentions risks to global growth but does not indicate a specific monetary policy stance or action."
}

stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{Annotation Guide} \\label{tb:bsp_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Policy} & When government spending decreases or financial regulations are tightened. & When government spending increases or financial regulations are loosened. & When policy statements maintain current spending levels or regulations. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Environment} & Energy prices fall, new price controls are implemented on fossil fuels, added subsidies for renewable energy, adverse effects of el niño. & Energy prices rise, production costs rise, or subsidies are removed. & When statements maintain current prices, confirm existing policy (e.g. subsidies, price controls) without signaling change. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Society} & When there is higher taxes, reduced subsidies, reduced social programs, or reduced minimum wages. & When there are lower taxes, increased subsidies, new social programs, or increases in minimum wages. & When societal measures are discussed with no clear indication of change to fields such as taxes, minimum wage, subsidies, or social programs. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Market} & When there is a reduction in interest rates, increase in the money supply, higher demand for loans, narrowing bond spread, higher bond yields. & Where there is an increase in interest rates, decrease in money supply, lower demand for loans, expanding bond spread, lower bond yields. & When there is no change in interest rates, money supply, or demand for loans. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Philippine peso appreciates, increased trade deficit, decreased exports. & Philippine peso depreciates, increased trade surplus, increased imports. & Maintained trade activity and currency valuation. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: meanwhile, domestic retail prices of petroleum products were raised twice in the same month following the recent uptrend in international prices and were raised anew on 1 february 2006 in line with the increase in the value added tax (vat) rate.\n                "}]
2025-05-03 20:25:04,840 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The increase in domestic retail prices of petroleum products and the rise in VAT rate may lead to higher inflation, which could warrant contractionary monetary policy."
}

Policies often impact laws and public services.\n    \\item \\emph{Environment}: Decisions related to environmental sustainability, energy consumption, or natural resources.\n    \\item \\emph{Society}: Decisions aimed at addressing the well-being of society. Policies often address income inequality, cost-of-living, and social programs.\n    \\item \\emph{Market}: Decisions that influence financial markets, including changes in interest rates, bond yields, and liquidity management.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: Decisions that impact trade, including imports, exports, exchange rates, and trade balances.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Maintain the BSP’s policy interest rates at 7.5 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) rate and 9.75 percent for the overnight RP (lending) rate; b.''\\\\\n 50 basis points to 4.50 percent for the overnight RRP (borrowing) facility, effective 28 September 2018; and, b) Adjust the interest rates on the overnight deposit and overnight lending facilities accordingly.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increase in interest rate and Reverse Repurchase Rate (RRP) signals contractionary monetary policy. \n\n    \\item ``- In August, the peso depreciated against the US dollar amid renewed global recession concerns as a result of protracted trade conflict between the US and China.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A depreciating peso in addition to unemployment rose to 10.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2002 as against 9.8 percent in the same period a year ago.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: A sharp increase in the unemployment rate signals
